meeting_annotations.speaker: Abhishek SINGHAROY
meeting_annotations.transcript: light, nutrients, these sort of things are not terribly bad. But once you get inside the cell and start doing engineering, it becomes quite difficult.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ronit Freeman
meeting_annotations.transcript: And also relates to to Lu's comments, it's also when we poke and at what time scale, what length scale, right? Which is also really important and how would that change. So there's the parameter space is actually huge.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Abhishek SINGHAROY
meeting_annotations.transcript: Mhm. Mhm.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Abhishek SINGHAROY
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's why we often don't even ask when as a part of the question. It might be in certain cases, but when is not as relevant, just what is important. It's easier possibly and then

meeting_annotations.speaker: Cathy Murphy
meeting_annotations.transcript: It is true, there's lots of papers where people, you know, they have a whole mouse or something, right? And they delete a whole gene from the animal, right? And then, you know, here's what happens. And then it's, you know, it's kind of a linear chain of thought, but as we've just been talking about, right, that might actually not be linear at all. It might be multiple cascades of stuff with feedback loops and then it looks linear, but it really might not be.
meeting_annotations.other: Uses expansive hand gestures to illustrate the concept of multiple cascades.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ronit Freeman
meeting_annotations.transcript: And even with that deletion itself, right? So like we actually have an NSF funded project where that the deletion itself, right, might get other parts in close proximity to turn on and off transcription that you didn't even think about. Right? Like that deletion itself, the way you alter would also most likely affect whatever is going on in the cell. So that that itself can be very, very damaging and and and get the cell into a different path.
meeting_annotations.other: Uses hand gestures to illustrate molecules coming into close proximity.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Michelle Farkas
meeting_annotations.transcript: So, so kind of to to maybe bring in a little bit of an element from the last, you know, session where we talked about extracellular entities and cell-cell communication, you know, in addition to how we poke, you know, what is the context of the cell that we're poking, right? So are we talking about, you know, needing to do single molecule or single, sorry, single cell studies where, you know, we're looking at, you know, one cell and a series of changes that are occurring through that cell versus a population of cells. And then you have to start thinking about, you know, what is the cell-cell variability, right? Because you can't necessarily say, especially when we start thinking about things like amplitude of signal and resulting effects that all cells are going to behave similarly, right? And so, you know, what what is the context within which we're going to be looking at these signaling events?

meeting_annotations.transcript: Yep. That's that's also, well, I guess it just means we should do a lot of, it means we're never going to run out of ideas to to study then, I guess. meeting_annotations.speaker: Masha Kamenetska
meeting_annotations.transcript: Just going to mention that we haven't talked much about mechanical signals. So I just wanted to throw that out there. So in the context of chromatin, for example, there's evidence that mechanical signals are obviously important.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Cathy Murphy
meeting_annotations.transcript: In chromatin? So what does that take the form of? Like you squish a cell and it suddenly starts expressing stuff?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Masha Kamenetska
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, no, just for example, RNA polymerase and Jan probably knows this better than me, applies force to the DNA to literally, right? So how does transcription occur? Well, there's some pulling that happens on a molecular level that liberates some region of DNA to be transcribed or does not and therefore that region does not get transcribed, for example. I'm not a biologist, but

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jan Spille
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, yeah, no, but that that's definitely true. And and Cathy, yes, it does happen. Mechanics are important for gene expression. And and say, I think it's in breast cancer cells, for example, if they migrate through certain tissue and it it depends on how soft or how stiff the tissue is that activates different expression programs which then lead to proliferation of the cells or not. So so that is is really a thing. I don't know exactly how it happens. There must be some some cascade coming through the cytoskeleton probably to the nucleus. Maybe it's just a volume change that makes different things accessible or or leads to different mechanisms like say condensate formation affected by density or or pressure in that sense, which then activates different parts. So so that's certainly a thinkable cascade.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Masha Kamenetska
meeting_annotations.transcript: And condensate formation is itself a sort of could be a sort of mechanical signal.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rommie Amaro
meeting_annotations.transcript: I want to also just mention, um, there, you know, there have been studies showing that membrane shape, cell membrane shape itself could potentially be, um, you know, another dimension of signaling. I don't think that's been mentioned yet, but I wanted to toss it in.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jan Spille
meeting_annotations.transcript: This is a really cool, it's a long time since I read those papers, but I think it's in Drosophila development and it needs to have a certain shape. If you delete certain factors, then the the tip of the embryo is going to lose its shape, but you can insert magnetic particles and then put a magnet next to the embryo to pull it back in shape and that rescues the phenotype under developmental scales, right? So multicellular organisms that know there's a curvature that we need at that tip to to become a fruit fly.
meeting_annotations.other: Uses hand gestures to describe the physical manipulation of the embryo's shape.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rommie Amaro
meeting_annotations.transcript: The Ronit, I do wonder, and this is the last thing I'll say because I try not to talk in these sessions because you all are doing such a great job. But also with these membrane studies where they look at shape, they often don't ever mention the word glycocalyx.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ronit Freeman
meeting_annotations.transcript: Exactly. Yeah, I was about to say that. I mean, and there started to be a little bit of work where people understand that the glycocalyx affects the mechanics of the membranes as well, and the diffusion, the mobility, the the lipid rafts, really everything. But it's normally ignored.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Masha Kamenetska
meeting_annotations.transcript: Like diffusion could set a natural length scale, right? And so how far a something diffuses can set the boundary, a natural boundary, and that's thus define a shape, I suppose.
